text.title: Be a Better Facilitator
text.head: Be a Better Facilitator
text.p: A “facilitator” is someone who acts as a 'lubricant' by helping a team with issues such as communications or problem solving but, typically, does not contribute to the actual content or management of a team's project (which is a team leader's function). Effective facilitation can help your organization maximize its resources by getting the most from the people who work with you. While there are a number of seminars, trainings and workshops to learn how to effectively facilitate or become certified as a facilitator, if you do not have the resources to hire a facilitator or become one, here are some tips to help get you started. Following are some tips for effective facilitation.
text.head: Steps

list.item:
Establish ground rules to encourage positive group interaction. Start with a few of your own and ask the group to for any others they would like to include. Some examples of ground rules:
Confidentiality. What is said in this room, stays in this room
Speak from your experience. Use “I” instead of “you” or “we”
There are no right or wrong answers. Our responses are based on our unique experience
Practice respect for myself and others
Listen actively. Respect others when they are talking.
Keep the focus of the conversation on the situation or issue.

item.ref: Maintain the confidence and esteem of all participants.

list.item: Control distractions, including distracting participants.

Develop participation.
As a facilitator, your talk time should be less than 40%
Ask open-ended questions
Be comfortable with silence – it may be a time of thought. Wait a full 10 seconds after asking a question.
Address people by name.
Use your personal experience as an example when appropriate.

text.head: Video
Tips

list.item: Be clear.
Speak clearly, at a moderate pace and an appropriate volume.
Transition smoothly from one activity or discussion to another.
Use visual aids to enhance and reinforce.
Ask for questions in an open manner – “What questions do you have?”
Use simple, straightforward words and sentences.
Enjoy the experience! If you are confident and have a good time, others will too!
Be prepared. Have an outline or a curriculum. Know what you want to achieve and be able to clearly articulate the desired outcome. Practice what you want to say, how you will say it.

text.head: Warnings

list.item: Manage over-participation.
Stay relaxed and un-defensive.
Handle aggressive behavior.
Avoid asking closed-ended questions.
Allow the other person to “save face”. Acknowledge the value of the person’s concerns.
Acknowledge that you hear and understand by paraphrasing.
Refer to the ground rules.
To get the group back on topic, ask participants to link the conversation to the issue you are discussing.

text.head: Things You'll Need

list.item: Markers and flip charts/white board
Outline or curriculum
Visual aids
Pens and paper for participants
